channel.title: Multilogging
channel.description:
How many will be allowed, and how will it be handled?
I think it should be a single instance per PC. This could be 'enforced' several ways. File locking, sockets, and sending the MAC address to the server.
Each method has their pros and cons, but if it's a single method you'll get a lot more people bypassing it.
In addition, are we going to keep track of logged in IP addresses, so we can see if someone is just using multiple PCs to bypass it?
Also, what will the punishment be for breaking this rule?

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can never trust anything the client sends you, and since the client has to send you the MAC address, I don’t think that will be very useful.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @NoLives NoLives
item.description:
@NoLives wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:40, topic:428094”]Ch3rry, you ever see that pk video… arguably the greatest pk vid ever with the red party hat in wild? The guy is fighting on his level 38 pure and gets 3 hit in level 2 wild. He spawns in lumby, logs off, logs onto main (who is also in lumby) and runs to edge. By the time he gets there about 10-15 seconds after the stuff spawn and like 20-30 people are clicking crazy and some level 14 ends up getting it.

The point is… he was on one account and only one account at a time, I myself have never multi logged, I either focus on one account or the other. Multilogging came into mainly in private servers. As this is a rsc replica… we should replicate the rsc experience… (I am not saying people didn’t do it)[/quote]No.
You’re the only person here with an underdeveloped brain.
You’re like an ipad, no multitasking.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Ch3rry, you ever see that pk video… arguably the greatest pk vid ever with the red party hat in wild? The guy is fighting on his level 38 pure and gets 3 hit in level 2 wild. He spawns in lumby, logs off, logs onto main (who is also in lumby) and runs to edge. By the time he gets there about 10-15 seconds after the stuff spawn and like 20-30 people are clicking crazy and some level 14 ends up getting it.

The point is… he was on one account and only one account at a time, I myself have never multi logged, I either focus on one account or the other. Multilogging came into mainly in private servers. As this is a rsc replica… we should replicate the rsc experience… (I am not saying people didn’t do it)

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @Ch3rry Ch3rry
item.description:
@Ch3rry wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:29, topic:428094”]Multiple accounts logged in at the same time should not be allowed debate…
I support fishing and afk training cb somewhere but I don’t support two accounts in the wild at the same time… so unfair.[/quote]
You’re not looking at the bigger picture here… Some people, “like myself” usually Afk train on high level accounts in the wild while pkn on border accounts or PBs… with these xp rates I’d imagine you’re not going to have people with three or four high level accounts that they can toggle in between after dying trying to pj.

The Enforcer:

Don’t go too far with these ‘Hardware ID’ ideas - you can stop legit players who won’t go manipulating the client, but that’s it.

Exactly… A simple VM being installed would allow your average Joe to abuse this. As for the hwid checker in general, Manual packet editing could even work in certain circumstances. BTW, are we talking about an actual auth HIWD DB save set for each account? (Which would but simply retarded)… Or just a scan to make sure X amount of accounts aren’t on each? Either way, It’d be bypassed by someone who’d care to put forth the effort. In the end, this will only hurt legit players, while favoring those it was meant to defend against.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“object, post:22, topic:428094”]You perhaps should read this about MAC addresses and Java, before introducing them as means for identifying clients:
https://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=2147365

In particular this:

Celarly something in 22 broke your code, but let’s step back from that. What do you want the MAC address for? The usual answer to this is ‘to uniquely identify the client’. If that’s the case here you are wasting your time, as MAC addresses don’t do that. They can be changed by the user. Ergo they don’t uniquely identify anything. Also I have known entire shipments of NIC cards to all have the same MAC address.

MAC addresses are only useful to Ethernet cards.
[/quote][/quote]The MAC address was one part of a multi-part solution. Also, it looks like it doesn’t work for unsigned applets, or when there is no actual connection. I do need to look into it more thoroughly though, and actually test it.

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:30, topic:428094”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=530781.msg3877909#msg3877909 date=1325797352]
Multiple accounts logged in at the same time should not be allowed debate…
I support fishing and afk training cb somewhere but I don’t support two accounts in the wild at the same time… so unfair.

I’m probably the only top pker in this thread, so u wouldn’t know if it’s fair or not, little rodger.[/quote]Obvious conflict of interests is obvious…

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

I think setting limits to maximum accounts one can own and maximum accounts one can have logged in will have negative effects. You’d most likely want to make a high level pker, a prayer beast, a low level pker, a staker, perhaps a fisher. It’s ok to afk on one account and pk on the other, perhaps even pk on multiple accounts at the same time.

Read full topic

no sharing personal info. I think when people want a replica they don’t want jagex’s sillyness.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I suggest the following. Since all characters will be registered to a forum account (that’s what I have understood), all you need to do, is check whether at least one character registered to the same forum account is already logged in. If that’s the case, simply do not allow that character in on the server.

Of course, then someone could create a new forum account or share accounts across two or more forum accounts. But the former is already against the rules - and I’m sure the latter would be too (implicitly).

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

The way I did it was simply saving IP’s into an ArrayList and then counting the ip address count upon login, if there’s 2 stored already it won’t let u login.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

You perhaps should read this about MAC addresses and Java, before introducing them as means for identifying clients:
https://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=2147365

In particular this:

Celarly something in 22 broke your code, but let's step back from that. What do you want the MAC address for? The usual answer to this is 'to uniquely identify the client'. If that's the case here you are wasting your time, as MAC addresses don't do that. They can be changed by the user. Ergo they don't uniquely identify anything. Also I have known entire shipments of NIC cards to all have the same MAC address.

MAC addresses are only useful to Ethernet cards.

Read full topic

item.title: Multilogging
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:20, topic:428094”]Oh okay, cool. I don’t suppose there are equivalents to get other information that would be useful for fingerprinting, such as hard disk and NIC identifiers? You’ll never have to worry about botting if proper hardware banning can be implemented in such a way that it’s not easy to bypass.[/quote]http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5482947/how-to-get-hard-disk-serial-number-using-java

NIC identifiers are the same as MAC addresses, correct?

Also, it can all be bypassed though modification of the client, or manipulation of the data being sent.

Read full topic
